comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Gladys and her mother, Mrs. Robert Hinckley figure frequently on the NYT society columns despite living in Washington. NYT November 21, 1909 [ query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9902E3DC143EE033A... ] has a picture of her and indicates that her father is a "well-known" artist. From the Washington Post of Sunday, November 19, 1911: Miss GLADYS HINCKLEY whom Baron Rosen former Russian Ambassador called the most beautiful woman in America has introduced the fad In Washington society of jeweled snakes either on the arm or as pendant to necklace bracelet or belt. See www.newspaperarchive.com/LandingPage.aspx?type=glp&se... hinckley&img=\\na0010\490248\5475490_clean.html Her costume is certainly unusual, but I'm not sure the decoration on the hat is a jewelled snake. Chapter 3 of Jannus, an American Flier by Thomas Reilly begins, "Gladys Hinckley, one of Washington's belles of society, earned a place in history on March 25, 1911, when she became the first woman to fly in an airplane in Washington, D.C." See books.google.com/books?id=hqXDkJ1gjS8C&pg=PA7&sou... On March 18, 1923, her marriage to McCeney Werlich of Paris was reported in the NYT (not a free article) at select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0B1EFB3D541673...
